Award.AwardTitle: A General and Efficient Framework for Computational Shape Analysis Through Geometric Distributions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The analysis of shapes and their variability has become an increasingly central problem in multiple areas of data science. In the field of computer vision, shape recognition and classification is often a crucial component of machine learning systems such as self-driving cars. In natural sciences, the recent development of computational anatomy, that is the automatic analysis of anatomical structures by numerical algorithms, provides a fruitful approach in understanding and diagnosing a wide range of pathologies and disorders. Along these different scientific questions, the amount and variety of available data has never ceased to grow. As a result, the concept of shape itself has considerably expanded and may refer to various types of geometric objects, which poses the important challenge of constructing and computing relevant similarity metrics between shapes across all these different modalities. The purpose of this research project is to develop an integrated mathematical model and associated numerical pipeline that allows for morphological analysis of geometric structures in a flexible and efficient way, and explore its possible applications to computational anatomy and computer vision. It will also include a substantial educational component with the training of a graduate student, support for presentations in conferences and workshops, and dissemination of an open-source code to the scientific community.

The primal challenge of statistical shape analysis is the rather non-standard and disparate mathematical spaces in which objects belong, whether the shapes in question are raw images, manually or automatically extracted landmarks, curves, surfaces, vector fields or multi-modal objects. While the seminal model proposed by Grenander introduced the idea of comparing any two shapes through the estimation of an optimal deformation (measured by a metric on a certain diffeomorphism group), this model's generality falls short in many real applications where a certain amount of residual dissimilarity is necessary to account for other sources of variability (like noise). This project intends to fill this current gap by introducing a flexible approach to quantify shape similarity which relies on a unified embedding of shape spaces as generalized distributions, following the principles of geometric measure theory. Beyond the past success of these representations for curve and surface registration problems, the objective will be to demonstrate on a mathematical and computational level how it extends to a much wider class of geometric data structures and allows for cross-modality analysis, while pushing the scope of applications to other problems like clustering, classification and sparse representations on shapes. Fast numerical methods for this new framework is also an important aspect of the project, with the objective of making implementations scalable to the current dimensionality of datasets e.g. in medical imaging.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quantitative morphological analysis of the shape of geometric structures is a widespread problem in many scientific domains, and its interest has only been expanding in the era of data science. With datasets of ever increasing size and complexity, developing adequate mathematical frameworks and corresponding robust numerical methods to extract essential patterns in the data is generally one of the key to take full advantage of this recent data revolution.

Throughout the funding period, the PI together with PhD students and collaborators have worked on new approaches for the construction and computation of metrics on shape spaces which can be used to perform different tasks including comparison, interpolation, compression or statistical analysis on geometric datasets. Specifically, the research team has explored the use of shape representations based on concepts from geometric measure theory as an efficient setting to obtain novel variational formulations for shape analysis tasks as well as scalable algorithms. They showed that these representations can be successfully integrated within Riemannian frameworks such as the elastic and diffeomorphic shape models. A systematic study of the well-posedness of these variational problems, optimality conditions and consistency under discrete approximations was conducted for the respective models, leading to several new mathematical results. On the numerical side, the team developed two code libraries in MATLAB and Python which were shared with the scientific community. The results obtained so far on synthetic as well as real data have evidenced how these new approaches can, on the one hand, effectively extend diffeomorphic shape analysis methods to a broad range of geometric data structures beyond traditional curves and surfaces and, on the other hand, provide a simpler and more robust way to tackle the reparametrization invariance constraint in elastic shape matching problems. This work has lead to a total of three journal publications, three conference papers, two book chapters and one additional journal manuscript currently under review. It also contributed in establishing a lasting and extensive collaboration between the PI and researchers at Florida State University.

The project has further allowed to support one full-time PhD student who will complete his dissertation on this topic by the end of the semester. It also provided summer support to an incoming graduate student who is now working with the PI towards his PhD in that same research area. The whole team has been invested in various dissemination activities through their participation in multiple conferences which included the 2019 ASILOMAR conference on Signals, Systems, and Computers or the 2020 SIAM conference on Mathematics of Data Science. They organized two minisymposia, at the 2018 SIAM conference of Imaging Sciences and 2019 Geometric Science of Information conference respectively. Finally, two software code repositories were created and openly shared on Github, which were accompanied with detailed documentations and running examples so as to promote reproducible research to the largest extent and hopefully spread the use of such tools to researchers from different scientific areas and background.

Aside from its mathematical and computational aspects, this research is deeply rooted into applications, most notably to the biomedical field where morphological analysis of signals or anatomical structures can be an important part of understanding pathologies and establishing diagnoses. Along those lines, the PI is currently investigating how the developed tools from this project could be applied to extract relevant morphological features of osteoarthritis in the knee joint and could provide new biomarkers for potential early diagnosis of a disease that carries such a significant healthcare burden. As part of the project itself, the PI also participated in a collaborative work to leverage diffeomorphic models for automatic emotion transfer between human speech utterances. This problem is specifically motivated by the study and diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder.
